utterances: Pasero has covered herself with Giuliani bumper stickers.
She even has one on her forehead.
And she's waiting for her chance to get a photo.
With all the signs I have on my body, he can't miss me.
Pasero eventually gets her 10 seconds with the candidate and a photo too.
Here we go.
All right, there you go.
Thank you.
It isn't much of a conversation.
A voters in Iowa or in New Hampshire might feel slighted, but Pasero doesn't seem to mind.
As far as I'm concerned, Rudy's at the top of my list right now.
So you might be wearing another person's sticker on your forehead or never?
No, I don't know.
That's debatable.
Right now I'd say no.
For NPR News, I'm Adam Burke.
A.J.
MINOR: They always used to like make us not strip down all the way, but they would make us take off our shoes and open up shirts and stuff.
They would pat us down and our pockets had to be turned out.
During his mom's absence, A.J.
was raised by several family members, since his father was also in prison, serving a life sentence.
Altogether, it nearly did A.J.
in.
A.
MINOR: I did have a lot of suicidal tendencies.
And it really sucked to have to go through that when you're 8, 9 and 10 years old, and 11 years old, and you're thinking about going into your room and killing yourself.
But instead of taking his life, A.J.
took action.
At just 15, he joined a fledgling task force that was taking shape in Coconino County, Arizona.
The group's goal was to keep kids connected with their parents in prison.
And that's where he met Beth Tucker, one of the group's organizers.
Our population of children and families is different than the state as a whole.
We have such great distances for our rural areas of families.
They're traveling hundreds and hundreds and hundreds of miles to visit a parent.
Tucker says about 1 in every 28 children in Coconino County has at least one parent in prison.
Some kids, like A.J., experience the trauma of being present during their parent's arrest.
Others, Tucker says, can end up on the street, fearful they'll land in foster care.
We know that oftentimes when parents are arrested, they will not reveal that they have children.
They're afraid they're going to lose the child.
And that's why law enforcement officers are now being trained to look for signs of children at the time of a person's arrest - toys, car seats, backpacks.
Another major step is that the county is installing a Skype-like video visitation system.
Lieutenant Matt Figueroa with the sheriff's office is helping set it up.
They can do it from a coffeehouse.
They can do it from their iPhone, iPad.
You know, people throw out the word Skype, but it's basically a secure video connection to be able to conduct that visit.
Figueroa says it will also cut down on the trauma that many kids experience having to go inside prison to visit a parent.
And that's heartening to kids like A.J.
Minor, who says he would've liked something like this when his mom was in prison.
A.

MINOR: A visit with your parent like that would actually keep a kid from running away, because they know that if they stay there they can have a visit with their parent every week, every couple of days.
It's so much more nourishing.
For someone that's going through it right now, hang on.
You will be able to see them.
A.J.
is trying to hang on himself when it comes to seeing his own father.
They haven't met face-to-face in 16 years.
For NPR News, I'm Gillian Ferris Kohl in Flagstaff.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
This is NPR News.

In Cairo, five strangers find themselves on a quest - a drug runner, a journalist, an American ex-pat, a troubled student, and an Israeli soldier - race to recover a stolen hookah that's home to a genie.
And before it's over, they learn a great deal more - about magic, about the city of Cairo and about themselves.
Cairo"" is a new graphic novel drawn by M.K.
Perker and written by G.
Willow Wilson, who splits her time between Egypt and the U.S., and freelances for publication including the New York Times and the Atlantic Monthly.
She joins us today from member station KXOT in Seattle, Washington.
Nice to have you on TALK OF THE NATION.
Ms.
G.
WILLOW WILSON (Author, ""Cairo""): Thank you for having me.
And I want to ask you, of the two interests of yours that led to the creation of this book - that being comic books and the city of Cairo - I assume your interest in comic books came first?
Actually, yes, it did.
People usually assume that comics were kind of a derailing from journalism for me.
But, actually, the reverse is true.
I've been a fan of comics since I was old enough to read, and it's a medium that I've enjoyed and followed all my life.
And being in Cairo and experiencing the nuances of life there - one of the first things I thought was someone should write a graphic novel about this city or set in the city.
So, yes, it did come first.
And, Cairo, you became interested in, when?
You know, it's actually kind of a coincidence.
I have studied Arabic and Middle Eastern history when I was in college.
And I knew I wanted to live and work for a time in the Middle East to feel what it's like on the ground, to see if what I'd heard on the news and in the classroom kind of held up to reality.
And it so happened that I was offered a job teaching in Cairo and that's the reason I moved.
And so it was sort of a coincidence, but an inspired coincidence.
How's your Arabic?
Now, it's all right.
My Egyptian colloquial is pretty good.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I can certainly get around.
This is, obviously, not an autobiographical graphic novel, I guess.
Mm-hmm.
But in many ways, I guess, it is a product of your own history.
In a sense, yes, it is.
I mean, emotionally, certainly, a lot of the characteristics of the people who are in the book are drawn from experiences that either I have had or people close to me have had in the Middle East.
And so, even though, obviously, it's a fantastic book, though it's certainly a comic book.
You know, there are elements of surrealism and magic and all these different things.

Emotionally, and also in some sense of - politically, I am drawing on the lives and the positions and the feelings of people that I know, you know, who have lived in the Middle East or who have a background that kind of draws them to these places.

One of the characters in the book in particular I wanted to ask you about, and that's the Egyptian journalist who - we meet him initially bewailing his faith and his inability to get anything published in the, well, rather, strictured and censored press in Egypt, but eventually reengages in the issues involved in the book.
Mm-hmm.
Yeah.

That's fine, you know, and I relish that, you know, because, you know, I think that one, people see people from the surface or, you know, from the outer appearance and things like that but don't know the person.
They get surprised by a lot of things and I think that that's where I drive on.
It catches some people off guard because when they think they know you, they really don't.

You know, there are so many aspects to your life that are depicted in the book - your family, relationships, especially, which I supposed like everybody else are rather complex - your grandpa, your dads - plural - and, of course, Dwight Gooden, your uncle.
Tell me how your family background turned you into the man as well as the player that you've become today.
Because, you know, I watched a strong father figure in my dad and my granddad.
And, you know, they kept the family, you know, afloat - kept everybody strong, you know, all of the man figures of my family was tough guys, you know.
They wouldn't, you know, no pushover guys.
They weren't guys.
They just, you know, I'll-tell-you-want-you-want-to-hear-type thing.
And then, you know, my uncle's father was most famous baseball player at the time in the '80s and, you know, he was the Michael Jordan figure of baseball.
So I've seen a different scenario, of ways things get done and I felt like with my personality and the type of player that I was, you know, they've kind of made me a whole, you know, a whole person.
Of course, I don't take nothing off on nobody, but at the same time, I know how to pick my spot to choose, you know, to fight my battles.
And also I care about people.
You know, as I read the book, Gary, I sensed a certain amount of hurt when you talked about finding out who your biological father was.
Well, yeah.

I mean, you know, it was just one of those things where, you're a young kid and you know, when you play as kids and some - and the way I was told that - you know, about my biological father, it - that was the hurtful part about it.
But, you know, as the type of person I am, I get over things pretty quick.
And I was able to just move on from it because I know I have two loving parents who were there for me, you know, through everything.
So you know, it was easy for me to get over it after I talked about it.
